column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0480] Fab' fragments may be directly recovered from E. coli and chemically coupled to form bispecific antibodies.
#Text=Shalaby et al., J.
#Text=Exp.
#Text=Med., 175: 217-225 (1992) describe the production of a fully humanized bispecific antibody F (ab')2 molecule.
#Text=Each Fab' fragment was separately secreted from E. coli and subjected to direct chemical coupling in vitro to form the bispecific antibody.
#Text=[0481] Various techniques for making and isolating bispecific antibody fragments directly from recombinant cell culture have also been described.
#Text=For example, bispecific antibodies have been produced using leucine zippers.
#Text=[0482] Kostelny et al., J.
#Text=The leucine zipper peptides from the Fos and Jun proteins were linked to the Fab' portions of two different antibodies by gene fusion.
#Text=The antibody homodimers were reduced at the hinge region to form monomers and then re-oxidized to form the antibody heterodimers.
#Text=This method can also be utilized for the production of antibody homodimers.
#Text=[0483] The "diabody" technology described, for example, by Hollinger et al., Proc.
#Text=Natal.
#Text=Acad.
#Text=Sci.
#Text=USA 90: 6444-6448 (1993) has provided an alternative mechanism for making bispecific antibody fragments.

#Text=The fragments comprise a heavy-chain variable domain (VH) connecte to a light-chain variable domain (VL) by a linker which is too short to allow pairing between the two domains on the same chain.
#Text=[0484] Accordingly, the VH and V, domains of one fragment are forced to pair with the complementary VL and VH domains of another fragment, thereby forcing two antigen-binding sites.
#Text=Another strategy for making bispecific antibody fragments by the use of single-chain Fv (sFv) dimers has also been reported.
#Text=See, Gruber et al., J.
